title: Can true wireless charging ever be achieved? What will be the pros and cons of such a technology? - Quora

response.answer_text: We have true wireless charging. We’ve had it for awhile… like, since before I was born. When I was a kid, I had an electric toothbrush that charged, wirelessly, in its stand. The good news here: unlike previous electric toothbrushes, this one didn’t plug directly into 110/220V power… kind of not what I want in my mouth. The bad news was that the first GE toothbrushes with wireless charging, as early as 1959 I believe, held enough charge for maybe 2–3 toothbrushings.  This used basic magnetic induction: an AC signal goes though a coil (in electronics, a device called an inductor) in the base, creating a varying magnetic field. Another coil, in the toothbrush, now becomes a coil of wire in a moving electric field, and current starts to flow in that coil. That’s an alternating current that the charging circuit in the toothbrush will rectify to direct current and apply to charge the toothbrush’s battery.  Pretty much all of today’s systems using inductive charging, just like that toothbrush from the 1960s. The problem here is energy loss. Any normal electromagnetic energy drops off as the square of the distance it’s travelling — this is called the inverse square law. But there is a trick used in radio that can help. If you take a perfect antenna that radiates the same in every direction, that’s said to be a 0dBi antenna, and power out of that antenna will go everywhere, but drop off pretty fast. But if I don’t send that energy everywhere, but restrict it in just one direction, I get what’s called an antenna gain. Some very high gain Yagi antennas can offer a 20dBi gain. So the signal effectively gets a huge boost before being transmitted out and falling off at the usual inverse square rate. The problem is that make the transmission very focused… it’s aimed precisely at a small target. That’s not going to work if you want even medium-range wireless charging, say, a charger that could get every phone on your conference table. Ok, sorry, just kidding… I did say magnetic energy, didn’t I? Power dropping off from a monopole will obey the inverse-square law, but inductive systems are dipolar, and the power actually drops off with the inverse-cube of the distance! The reason you’re dropping your iPhone directly on top of charging pad is because of this. Standard Qi inductive charging is near-field charging only. Even a few extra millimeters is going to dramatically affect the coupling efficiency.  But again, the radio world already has a solution, which is already used on your local cellphone tower and in some of the new 802.11ac hotspots: beamforming. Basically, rather than have a very high gain antenna, a transmitter will have a large number of normal antennas that can vary their phase very accurately, creating a phased array. Timing this just so, a set of small antennas can form a directional beam just like a big directional antenna, with the same inherent gain, but it can be pointed anywhere. And sure enough, there’s a company working on that, using the Qi standard for charging, that’s getting at least medium-range charging out of it. Maybe not the whole conference table, but all the phones put near the charger, rather than trying to all sit on the charger. See: Pi can wirelessly charge your phone from a short distance. Beating the Inverse-Square Law Ok, you can’t possibly defeat the Inverse-Square/Cube Law. But you can boost the power of your signal up so high, form a beam so narrow, that it might seem to be doing that. What’s really happening is that you’re getting more of the energy delivered to your device’s antenna, less to the rest of the world. This works because the inverse-square law isn’t really about power loss… it’s about power spreading. The area over which the energy from your device spreads is what is following the inverse square law. If the width of the beam at your device is smaller than the receiving antenna, you’re not losing much energy. Another recent trick being employed by some systems, including the popular Qi standard, is a thing called magnetic phase synchronous coupling, or Resonant inductive coupling. This is a particularly low-loss means of coupling for wireless energy transfer. Some folks at MIT conducted a project in 2006 that delivered power to a 60W light bulb via 20 inch coils across a distance of 7 feet with 45% efficiency. So sure, you’re losing 55% of the energy, but with a standard inductive charger, you’d drop too much power in 7″ to be of any use. So that IS progress. And oh-by-the-way, those folks went on to found a company called WiTricity, commercializing medium-range power delivery via magnetic phase synchronous coupling… they claim they’re getting a million times more efficiency in transmission than a non-resonant inductive system. So given that this question is unqualified, I don’t know the exact definition the OP has for “true wireless charging”, given that we’ve truly had it for decades. Longer distance will be real, but it’s not as if mankind really needs a way to waste an additional 25% or 50% of all the power we generate. At least not yet. So hopefully, this is used sparingly and only where it’s really useful. Update: Someone Is Releasing a System Ok, so it does look like a company, Ossia (Ossia: Proven Wireless Power Technology You Can Use Today) is at least talking with technology companies about their wireless system, which seems to be a high frequency resonant system with beamforming — they claim 100 antennas in the transmitter, which ought to let them deliver a really tight focus to a receiver. That said, they are not claiming to beat physics, which is good. The system can deliver a 3W charge to devices very close to it, reduced to “milliwatts” for devices further away.  The basic Cota Tile transmitter is a replacement for a ceiling tile, which has fairly limited applications, it’s huge, but they claim about two of these will cover a 3000sqft house. They’ll probably have something less weird at some point, but being on the ceiling gives it the advantage of not being quite so easily blocked by furniture, pets, people, etc.  And they also have this: wirelessly recharged AA batteries. Do I want there? Well, the basic design means there’s a batetry and a whole wireless charging system in every battery. So their capacity as stand-alone will suck. But how about your AA-powered TV remote control. That has batteries that maybe last a year or more. That slow charge rate, even from a distance, is good enough to basically make your remote, my several battery powered Nest Protect fire alarms, etc. immortal, with batteries only being replaced as the internal cell fails. So I think, if you’re expecting this to charge your phone, it probably fails compared to a close-up charger. But I also have a few lithium-cell powered IoT devices, which run maybe two years on a battery. If I could drop in a CR123 or whatever replacement battery and mostly never worry again about replacing batteries (and when I did, the Cota system would warn me about future battery failure long before the devices would), I would be interested. Over all, it probably can’t be a cost savings thing. But measured against decades, they might be offering an overall cleaner solution, environmentally, even given the 10x or so power needed for remote nodes. It does mean fewer batteries in landfills. It’s interesting to me, when you’re looking at micropower. See more here: Ossia Debuts Next-Gen Cota® Tile at CES 2018, This Wireless Charging 'Forever Battery' Will Never Die Dave Does the Math And from the comments, it’s clear that some readers are just not getting this. Or the fact that when the manufacturers speak of wireless charging, they are speaking of just the device, not that you’ll magically eliminate any wire anywhere near the phone. Again, micropower IoT is not the same thing, but so many folks think about wireless power throught the house in terms of their phone, we need to look there. Some have asked why charging can’t be like Wifi, and just work anywhere in the room. Here’s a good example of why. Your typical Wifi access point transmits are sending at a power level o 20dBm = 100mW… that’s the power going into the antenna. And sure, you can get higher power radios, I had a 500mW device in my old, very large house, but even that’s not legal in every country. Your phone, your laptop, any other wireless device will work just dandy with a received signal at -60dBm, or 0.000001mW. There is no problem in losing all that energy between devices just to send information. If your device could live on microwatt power, day to day, you’d be spending 10x-100x the power to charge it, but that would at least be doable. At 100mW — the power going into the antenna on your WiFi device — it would take about five to six days to charge your average smartphone with a 100% efficient power reciver. That’s of course completely silly, since that wouldn’t even beat the use-rate of the power from your phone. At 0.000001mW, it would take well over a million years to charge your smartphone… and that’s ignoring the 2–3% self-discharge rate of Li-ion cells per month. As mentioned, there have been some schemes like magnetic phase synchronous coupling matched with beamforming that essentially follows you around with a tightly focused beam of power… if it’s just you. Each additional device is going to make the system less efficient, and you’re already talking about paying 2x, 4x, maybe even more in practical systems to get a charge to fly maybe a meter or so through the air. So now think about this… to charge my phone in an hour, the power brick I have plugged in will be delivering about 12W of power. To shoot that through the air a meter or so, I’ll need something like 48W, maybe a bit more, maybe that’s enough. You don’t want to go too high… we have another device that throws energy into the air at high frequencies, but usually more like 500W or more. It’s called a microwave oven. And before you cry foul, consumer microwaves operate in the 2.4GHz band. The exact same RF band occupied by Wifi and Bluetooth. And the same band WiTricity chose to send energy across that meter’s gap. I already have eight different wireless systems in my house at 100mW or less… not sure I want a 50W-100W transmitter or two in every room.

currently wireless charging is very limited. Items are usually on top of a charging pad and the wireless charging is very short in range. True wireless charging would be entering a room or area and your device automatically transfers energy. Can you imagine the applications? we wouldn’t really need larger batteries, our devices would constantly be at a charge. we could invest our mobile phones to push more developments since energy constrains are now lifted. Within a short times pan you could see Mixed reality devices that wont rely on a battery pack, phones with the capability of a modern console or pc. if we moved wireless to their furthest extent, no more stopping for gas or energy station while driving! Drive on a energy shoulder lane and bam your energy vehicle is good to go for another few miles! Being able to transfer energy on a large scale would be phenomenal! Although cons there’s probably military applications and the like, but the applications would be endless!
